Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Situation2: They notice a minor ethical dilemma at work, like someone cutting in line, and feel a mild urge to act.
Story: Tonight is the only evening I have with Arjun before he leaves for a week, and I want nothing more than to make it special. We’ve planned this dinner for days, and I can see how much he’s looking forward to it too. As we wait for our table at the restaurant, I notice a coworker from my office quietly slipping ahead in the reservation line, pretending not to see the others waiting. My upbringing as a Hindu tugs at me—my parents always taught me to stand up for what’s right, even in small things. I feel a responsibility to say something, to gently remind her of fairness and honesty. But Arjun squeezes my hand, his eyes full of anticipation, and I know he just wants to forget about work and enjoy our rare time together. My heart pounds as I weigh the urge to speak up against the desire to keep our evening light and undisturbed. The two parts of me—devoted girlfriend and principled Hindu—pull in opposite directions, and I can’t ignore the tension building inside.
